Since the original email was from (presumably) an american in america
wh=
o wanted to get body art that reflected his interest in martial arts
and th=
e Samurai as a personal (maybe even relatively private depending
on the loc=
ation) symbol of his own interests, I didn't even consider
or see any relat=
ionship to Japan or the Samurai, which is why I had
trouble making sense ou=
t of what you meant.  I would agree with you if
he was in/going to Japan an=
d/or wanted to show off his tattoos to
Japanese people to show how much of =
a Samurai he is, but I didn't
really get that impression. It seemed pretty =
innocent, actually. So
since it seemed to me that it was an innocent reques=
t by an american
in america, it was easy for me to take your statement as a=
 statement
of your personal feelings for tattoos.  And I've seen plenty of =
people
in Japan with tattoos, it isn't as bad as it used to be.  I even kne=
w
a Japanese highschool teacher with tattoos around his collarbone,
where h=

respectable. Anyway, =
you really can't make a blanket statement that
"NO 'respectable' Japanese p=
erson would get a tattoo", because it
would only take one person to get one=
